slideInfo.mainText: In his short story “Reason,” Asimov reveals his suspicious feelings toward technology by creating unnatural conditions, making the main character uncertain, and concluding with an ironic statement. Asimov warned his reader in 1941 of a technology whose reasoning could match—if not exceed—human capabilities. We know that artificial intelligence is a reality today, and seeing the incredible technological advancements in our own lifetime, we might expect to see a robot like QT in the near future. Currently, our technology speaks to us through a variety of devices: vehicles beep to warn us that an object is behind us, calculators answer our math problems, and computers ask us to consider our spelling and grammar errors. How would we feel if our cell phone questioned our abilities? Our intelligence? Even now, smart phones have a talking feature that answers the owner’s questions. So, with its performance capabilities, who could blame the device if it said to us, “For you to make me seems improbable.”
